div.p:
You lay me under fresh obligations not ony by the print of Ld Herbert
Bull may have sent a print of one of the several 'Herberts' named in Pennant, A tour in Wales.MDCCLXX, vol. 2: William Herbert, earl of Pembroke, alive in 1468 (p. 121); Edward Lord Herbert, alive during the reign of Edward VI (p. 368); William Herbert, who sat in parliament for the borough of Montgomery in 1542 (p. 373; = ?William Herbert, first earl of Pembroke, 1506/7–1570), soldier and magnate; ODNB); Richard Herbert, d.1597, 'father to the famous Lord Herbert' whose monument at Montgomery church Pennant noted (p. 378); Sir William Herbert, second son of the earl of Pembroke; created Lord Powys; alive during the reign of Elizabeth (p. 378); Lord Edward Herbert (p. 379). & others contained in the Box sent to Moses: but by the genteel & beautiful present you made him. He has the most grateful sense of it: & offers his best acknowlegements. It came only last night. The delay was owing to the neglect of my carrier.

In the P.S. is a translation of Glyndwr's verses The postscript has not been preserved with the manuscript letter. This description given of its contents may indicate that it contained the cywydd, 'Eryr digrif afrifed / Owain &c', by Gruffudd Llwyd ap Dafydd ab Einion Lygliw. See Rhiannon Ifans, Gwaith Gruffudd Llwyd a’r Llygliwiaid Eraill (Aberystwyth, 2000), no. 11. It was translated by Richard Williams, Fron, for inclusion in A tour in Wales. MDCCLXX, vol. 1, pp. iii, 311–15. Perhaps this is not the right work, however, since this would have been published already and Bull would therefore have no need of a translation. You will see that there is not much in them. In p vol II. is as full an account as I could give of Pistill Rhaidr I am very happy in a print you sent me of that waterfall.

As you are silent about the house I gave you an account of I suspect it is not to your purpose. I wish it may be so for I have since learned that it is quite unfurnished. I shall be sorry
should you have changed your mind about Wales for many reasons. one is that I have an offer of another house ready furnished, & a place you very as well acquainted with by description or Moses & I are bunglers. see
Tower p. 399 of welsh tour vol. I.
Tower, near Mold, Flintshire, is described as stated by Pennant in A tour in Wales. MDCCLXX, (London: Henry Hughes, 1778), vol. 1, pp. 399–400. It belongs to a worthy young gentleman who married the heiress but in may is going to reside at his own house, Leeswood see p. the same. Leeswood was the property of the Eyton family.
